text: hi my name is Jennifer de Rossi DeCosta
I'm a certified diabetes educator and
registered nurse for Southwest hospitals
group and today I'd like to talk to you
about insulin pump therapy insulin pumps
are small page like devices that deliver
insulin they deliver insulin in two
different ways one way is that it
delivers insulin in a slow fashion a
continuous fashion which is called a
basal rate this basal rate runs
continuously for 24 hours it's very
similar to what you might already be
using for insulin called Lantis or 11:00
ER which is continuous or slow acting
the insulin pump also uses insulin and
delivers it in a quick way it delivers
insulin as a large burst of insulin
which is called
a bolus a bolus would be delivered
through the pump anytime that you eat
grams of carbohydrate or anytime your
blood sugar is elevated for instance if
your blood sugar is above your target
you would give more insulin that's
called the bolus now I know this sounds
difficult to understand but actually
insulin pumps are pretty easy to use
prior to someone going on an insulin
pump you would be thoroughly trained on
how to use these now to clear up some
misconceptions insulin pumps are easy to
use with training there is not a
surgical procedure there's no surgery
involved most people feel that insulin
pumps are probably too fragile for your
lifestyle and that's actually a
misconception
insulin pumps are used by all types of
people from children to professional
athletes in addition to that pumps do
not know what your blood Sugar's are you
still have to monitor your blood sugar
and you basically tell the pump how much
insulin to give it does not know what
your blood sugars are so hopefully this
gets you thinking about what insulin
pumps are all about and we hope to see
you here I think it's a great tool for
people to use in fact I personally use
an insulin pump for the last 15 years
hope to see you at the diabetes program
at South Coast Hospitals group our
number is five zero eight three two four
three two six zero thank you
